frame.name: Interior_profile_relation
frame.definition:
<def-root>A <fen>Figure</fen> is located in the interior (the Profiled_region--see Locative_relation frame) of the <fen>Ground</fen>. Some members of this frame indicate the plexity of the <fen>Ground</fen>, as either single-entity gestalt (inside), two-entity or bi-partite gestalt (between), and multiple-entity or multipart gestalt (among, amid), while others are maximally general (in). <ex></ex> This frame makes use of the Bounded_region image schema, a way of partitioning a scene into an Interior, an Exterior, and a Boundary. In some cases, the Boundary may be a physical entity that inhibits motion ("in a box"), while in other cases it may be based on a category boundary where properties change ("in the garden"). The LUs that specifically pick out two-entity or multi-entity <fen>Ground</fen>s imply the lack or irrelevancy of a physical barrier. <ex></ex> This frame is used in several productive metaphor cases. It is used to describe the timing of events relative to other events or periods, with per target differentiation or homogeneity of the <fen>Ground</fen> events that serve as a reference, based on the literal use of a target ("amid the confusion", "inside the competition period", "between lunch and dinner"). It is also used in a productive metaphor that locates emotional and cognitive states within an individual ("I felt an unease inside me.").
<ex><fex name="Figure">She</fex> <ment>stood</ment> <t>in</t> <fex name="Ground">a puddle</fex> and splashed desultorily .</ex> <ex>I <ment>felt</ment> around <t>inside</t> <fex name="Ground">the oven hood</fex> . <fex name="Figure">CNI</fex></ex> <ex>They found the backpack and <ment>found</ment> <fex name="Figure">a computer</fex> <t>inside</t> . <fex name="Ground">DNI</fex></ex>
This frame is intended to cover cases in which the <fen>Ground</fen> is a critical locus for the event. (When annotating the main verb in such a case, the locative phrase may be annotated on a second layer as Means, Instrument, or Cause.) <ex><fex name="Figure">The pole snapped off</fex> <t>in</t> <fex name="Ground">her hand</fex> .</ex> <ex><fex name="Figure">She combed her hair</fex> <t>between</t> <fex name="Ground">her fingers</fex> .</ex>
In some very specific situations, a prepositional phrase can be used with a copula to describe the whole <fen>Profiled_region</fen> where a <fen>Figure</fen> is or could be, as in the following:
<ex><t><fex name="Profiled_region">Inside</fex></t> <fex name="Ground">my wallet</fex> is where i put it .</ex> <ex><t><fex name="Profiled_region">Outside</fex></t> <fex name="Ground">your blind date's door</fex> seems like the worst place in the world .</ex>
<ex></ex> As in other locative frames, the LUs interact productively with other lexical and non-lexical frames. One of the more confusing cases is with verbs involving gaze, in the which the <fen>Figure</fen> is specified by the governing verb to be the gaze of the viewer, and thus from the viewpoint of the locative LU is CNI. See the following: <ex>They <m>looked</m> <t>among</t> <fex name="Ground">the trees</fex> for an hour . <fex name="Figure">CNI</fex></ex>
<ex></ex> This frame should not be used for cases in which the <fen>Ground</fen> element is a literal or metaphorical distance; see Within_distance. </def-root>

FE.name: Figure
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Figure</fen> is the entity located with respect to the <fen>Ground</fen>.
<ex><fex name="Figure">Ben</fex> is <t>in</t> the hallway.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Ground
FE.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Ground</fen> is the area that the <fen>Figure</fen> is located in.</def-root>

FE.name: Time
FE.definition: <def-root>The time during which the <fen>Figure</fen> was located in the <fen>Ground</fen>.</def-root>

FE.name: Direction
FE.definition:
<def-root>This FE identifies the <fen>Direction</fen> from a reference location (generally, the deictic center) of a path to the <fen>Figure</fen>.
<ex>The book is way <fex name="Direction">back</fex> <t>in</t> the Paleontology area.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Accessibility
FE.definition: <def-root>This FE identifies the <fen>Accessibility</fen> between the <fen>Figure</fen> and some reference location (generally, the deictic center or the <fen>Ground</fen>). <ex>The cat is <fex name="Acc">just</fex> <t>in</t> there.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Profiled_region
FE.definition:
<def-root>The area or zone interior to the <fen>Ground</fen>. This FE excludes <fen>Figure</fen> and is only used in particular constructions such as the following:
<ex><t>Inside</t> the cupboard <m>was</m> <fex name="Profiled_region">a good place to hide</fex> .</ex> <ex>We looked <fex name="Profiled_region"><t>between</t></fex> the trees .</ex> <ex>I found the ring <fex name="Profiled_region">in there</fex> , <t>in among</t> the old moldy rugs .</ex>
</def-root>

FE.name: Directness
FE.definition:
<def-root>An indication of how closely the position of <fen>Figure</fen> matches the prototype expected from the image schema associated with the target. This FE is normally filled by closed-class, dedicated adverbs like right, straight, directly, and due (and some combinations of these), but also occurs with rarer items like 'smack dab'.
<ex>I was standing <fex name="Directness">right</fex> <t>inside</t> the entrance of the church.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Temporal_profile
FE.definition:
<def-root>A description of how the access path to the <fen>Ground</fen> interacts with time. This FE is filled only by the closed class of adverbials back.adv (which indicates that the position was occupied by the <fen>Figure</fen> before) and on.adv (which indicates a continued path). While this FE in its most basic use refers to cases of actual motion, it can be used with descriptions of static position, in which case it either refers to fictive, imagined motion (as in the first example below), or it backgrounds motion entirely (as in the second example).
<ex>You 'll find it straight <fex name="Temporal_profile">on</fex> over <t>inside</t> the closet.</ex> <ex>He's already <fex name="Temporal_profile">back</fex> <t>in</t> the house.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Deixis
FE.definition:
<def-root>An indication of how the locative phrase relates to the grounding of the speech situation, either locating it near (here) or far (there, yonder), or specifically separated from the speech context by distance or a barrier (over). Fillers of this FE are restricted to this closed class of items.
<ex>It is lying <fex name="Deixis">here</fex> <t>among</t> the flowers.</ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Region_quantification
FE.definition:
<def-root>A description of how much of a potential profiled region actually has (or is expected to have) a <fen>Figure</fen> in it. It is normally filled by closed-class items like 'all', 'somewhere', 'nowhere', etc.
<ex>I think he's <fex name="Region_quantification">somewhere</fex> <t>within</t> the building.</ex></def-root>

lexUnit.name: in.prep
lexUnit.definition: FN: located such that motion in most directions would intersect with the boundary of.

lexUnit.name: inside.prep
lexUnit.definition: FN: within (the boundaries a profiled region)

lexUnit.name: among.prep
lexUnit.definition: FN: surrounded by (a group of entities).

lexUnit.name: within.prep
lexUnit.definition: FN: in (a well-defined space or boundaries), implying strictness of boundary and/or relevance of the entire interior space.

lexUnit.name: between.prep
lexUnit.definition: FN: located on a line from one entity to another, with both entities considered collectively as a pair.

lexUnit.name: amid.prep
lexUnit.definition: FN: surrounded by (a large or notable entity or entities).

lexUnit.name: in between.prep
lexUnit.definition: FN: physically located on a line from one group or entity to a separate group or entity.

lexUnit.name: in among.prep
lexUnit.definition: FN: located with (a collection of objects) surrounding in an irregular, jumbled, and possibly entangled fashion
